learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a detailed knowledge of corporate law and corporate governance including the role played by, and rights and duties of, shareholders, directors, managers and other stakeholders.
Demonstrate knowledge of legal and self regulation of corporate governance.
Demonstrate an awareness of different policy perspectives on corporate governance, and their legal implications.
Demonstrate knowledge of current reform proposals.

assessments.task_description:
During class, students will research and write answers to 4 tutorial problems (each is worth 5 marks).

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submissions will be submitted at the end of the class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Any student who does not complete the 4 tutorial problems at the respective class, will have an opportunity to complete one additional problem at the class on 6th May 2026.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Each student is to research and write a research essay on a topic chosen by him/her and approved by the Course Co-ordinator. Students should aim for their papers to be of publishable standard.

  1. The essay should be no more than 5,000 words in length (including references).  In cases where the Course Co-ordinator considers that a student may derive an unfair advantage over other students by exceeding the word limit the Course Co-ordinator will not assess material in excess of the prescribed word limit.
  2. The student's name and ID number must appear at the top of each page.
  3. All authorities must be properly referenced and cited following the Law School Citation Style - see s 3.4 of this profile for more information.
  4. Students must seek to show that they can comprehend the materials and present them accurately; analyse legislation and cases (where applicable); discern the principles and policies which underlie rules; produce critical review; and develop innovative answers to difficult cases.

The Assessment Criteria for the essay are included in the course Learning Guide.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Essays must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
There will be a final examination of 90 minutes duration plus 10 minutes planning time held during the end-of-the semester examination period. It will be an "open book" examination. Students should expect an examination with limited or no choice, covering the whole semester's work. The examination may contain problem questions, essay questions, or a mixture of both.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Seminar Series

The following topics will be covered over the four days of the course:

A. Introduction - The Concept of Corporate Governance
B. The Corporation and Corporate Law
C. Board Function and Composition
D. Governance Mechanisms
E. Not for Profit governance

A detailed programme will be included in the Learning Guide. The Learning Guide is available on the course Blackboard site.
